The M.Phil. in American Literature at the University
of Cambridge is a nine month course, which runs from October to June.
It is designed particularly for students wishing to approach the subject
from a secure foundation in the study of English literature. The focus
is on literary texts in their historical and intellectual contexts, as
seen in both generic and chronological perspectives. The course is cumulative
and self-contained, involves written exercises during the year, and leads
to a dissertation on a topic of the students choice. It aims to equip
each student with a firm historical and literary base, together with appropriate
The context of the American M.Phil. will thus be the
larger study of literature within the Faculty of English. This will allow
the course to draw upon the traditional strengths of the Cambridge English
Faculty, as well as allowing students to attend lectures or seminars on
a wide range of complementary subjects, from Elizabethan or Victorian
literature through to postcolonial writing and critical theory. M.Phil.
students participate in the American Graduate Seminar, held fortnightly
throughout the academic year, which features presentations by postgraduate
students or visiting faculty followed by informal discussion. Students

subjects unless they have completed the M.Phil. in American Literature
(or a similar postgraduate course) at an appropriate standard.

The period classes are designed to involve a close
study of the literature falling within a span of ten years or so, with
particular emphasis on specified texts and their relation to each other
and to the history of which they form a part. The current periods are
1845 to 1855 and 1915 to 1925. The earlier period aims to introduce
students to a variety of genres and texts including both canonical and
more marginal works. It might survey such topics as the representation
of nature, the Gothic, Transcendentalism, slave narratives, and the
development of the American poetic voice. Recent set texts have included
The Blithedale Romance, Narrative of the Life of Frederick
Douglass and poems by Whitman and Longfellow. The later period takes
up such matters as the development of American modernism, the role of
little magazines, experimental prose and the Harlem Renaissance, with
reference to such works as Spring and All, Harmonium,
in our time and Cane. Other issues that may be considered
here are literary reactions to economic and cultural change from novelists
such as Dos Passos, and the challenge to Broadway of alternative theatres
and the plays of Eugene O'Neill.

Applicants should normally have a first-class honours degree or high
II.i , or its overseas/international equivalent. Applicants whose first
degrees are in other disciplines are always considered, provided they
can give an account of how their interest in literary study has developed.
We welcome qualified UK, EU, and overseas applicants (those for whom English
is not a first language will be required by the Board of Graduate Studies
to provide evidence of linguistic proficiency).
Applicants should include specific proposals for advanced study or research
(of around 500 words). A piece of written work, of 5,000 - 7,500 words,
should accompany a formal application. Applicants may submit any work
they like, but it is worth choosing work which is recent and which relates
to your proposed area of study, if this is available. Many applicants
submit their undergraduate dissertation or similar extended piece of work.
